lambada.factcheck_selection:
Example 1
Fact1: Julie is reading a 120-page book. Fact2: Yesterday, she was able to read 12 pages and today, she read twice as many pages as yesterday. Fact3: If she wants to read half of the remaining pages tomorrow, how many pages should she read?
Question: What is the answer for the problem?
Inference: For the question what is the answer?, the most relevant fact is Fact1 Julie is reading a 120-page book.

Example 2
Fact1: Mark has a garden with flowers. Fact2: He planted plants of three different colors in it. Fact3: Ten of them are yellow, and there are 80% more of those in purple. Fact4: There are only 25% as many green flowers as there are yellow and purple flowers. Fact5: How many flowers does Mark have in his garden?
Question: What is the number of yellow flowers?
Inference: For the question What is number of yellow flowers?, the most relevant fact is Fact3 Ten of them are yellow.

Example 3
Fact1: Ursula bought five hot dogs at $1.50 each and three salads at $2.50 each. Fact2: If she had two $10 bills, how much change did she get back?
Question: How much change did ursula get back?
Inference: For the question How much change did ursula get back?, the most relevant fact is Fact1 Ursula bought five hot dogs at $1.50 each.

Example 4
Fact1: A truck driver has to spend $2 per gallon of gas. Fact2: She can drive 10 miles per gallon. Fact3: She drives at a rate of 30 miles per hour. Fact4: If she is paid $.50 per mile, how much money does she make if she drives for 10 hours?
Question: How much money did the driver spend on gas?
Inference: For the question How much money did the driver spend on gas?, the most relevant fact is Fact1: A truck driver has to spend $2 per gallon of gas.

Example 5
Fact1: Building A has 4 floors, which is 9 less than Building B. Fact2: Building C has six less than five times as many floors as Building B. Fact3: How many floors does Building C have?
Question: How many floors does Building A have?
Inference: For the question How many floors does Building A have?, the most relevant fact is Fact1 Building A has 4 floors.

lambada.rule_implication:
Example 1
Rule1: Julie is reading a 120-page book. Rule2: Yesterday, she was able to read 12 pages and today, she read twice as many pages as yesterday. Rule3: If she wants to read half of the remaining pages tomorrow, how many pages should she read?
Inference: Rule1 implies (), Rule2 implies (pages julie read today), Rule3 implies (pages julie want to read tomorrow, answer for the problem).

Example 2
Rule1: Mark has a garden with flowers. Rule2: He planted plants of three different colors in it. Rule3: Ten of them are yellow, and there are 80% more of those in purple. Rule4: There are only 25% as many green flowers as there are yellow and purple flowers. Rule5: How many flowers does Mark have in his garden?
Inference: Rule1 implies (), Rule2 implies (), Rule3 implies (number of purple flowers), Rule4 implies (number of green flowers), Rule5 implies (number of total flowers; answer for the problem).

Example 3
Rule1: Ursula bought five hot dogs at $1.50 each and three salads at $2.50 each. Rule2: If she had two $10 bills, how much change did she get back?
Inference: Rule1 implies (total price of hotdogs; total price of salads; total price of hotdogs and salads), Rule2 implies (how much money Ursula had; answer for the problem)

Example 4
Rule1: A truck driver has to spend $2 per gallon of gas. Rule2: She can drive 10 miles per gallon. Rule3: She drives at a rate of 30 miles per hour. Rule4: If she is paid $.50 per mile, how much money does she make if she drives for 10 hours?
Inference: Rule1 implies (), Rule2 implies (), Rule3 implies (), Rule4 implies (total time of driving, answer for the problem).

Example 5
Rule1: Building A has 4 floors, which is 9 less than Building B. Rule2: Building C has six less than five times as many floors as Building B. Rule3: How many floors does Building C have?
Inference: Rule1 implies (number of floors in building b), Rule2 implies (number of floors in building c), Rule3 implies (answer for the problem).

least_to_most.decomposition:
Question: Joyce had 37 blackcurrant. David confered him some more. Now Joyce has 134 blackcurrant. How many did David confer him?

Example 1
Question: Joyce had 37 blackcurrant. David confered him some more. Now Joyce has 134 blackcurrant. How many did David confer him?

Solution:
Q. How many blackcurrants did Joyce had initially?
A. Joyce had 37 blackcurrants.
Q. How many blackcurrants does Joyce has now?
A. Joyce has 134 blackcurrants
Q. How many blackcurrants did David confered to Joyce?
A. So david confered 134 - 37 = 97 blackcurrants to Joyce.
The answer is: 97.

Example 2
Question: A chef needs to cook 12 potatoes. He has already cooked 6. If each potato takes 6 minutes to cook, how long will it take him to cook the rest?

Solution:
Q. How many more potatoes should the chef cook?
A. The chef should cook 12 - 6 = 6 more potatoes.
Q. How long will it take him to cook the rest?
A. So the chef will need 6 * 6 = 36 minutes to cook all the potatoes.
The answer is: 36.

A. Joan had 47 green marbles.
Q. How many green marbles did Fred took from Joan?
A. Fred took 24 green marbles from Joan
Q. How many green marbles does Joan now have ?
A. Joan has 47 - 24 = 23 green marbles now.
The answer is: 23.

Question: A chef needs to cook 12 potatoes. He has already cooked 6. If each potato takes 6 minutes to cook, how long will it take him to cook the rest?
